article.title: LARPers Duel at Dogshit Park
article.description: Around 20 Isla Vista residents faought each other with foam-covered plastic pipes in live action role-play, also known as LARP.
article.content:
Around 20 Isla Vista residents charged into battle at “Dogshit Park” on Sunday afternoon, fighting each other with foam-covered plastic pipes in live action role-play, also known as LARP.

“Are you ready for glory?” shouted Tomek Fraczek, a fourth-year physics major, right before one of the battles.

Three members from the UCSB Excursion Club organized this year’s game after the tradition began two years ago.

Camoron Jordan, UCSB alumnus and one of the event organizers, said his friend, Nik Frey, organized the event for the last two years, and he wanted to continue the tradition out of “respect for him.”

While last year’s event raised money for Lymphoma research, third-year economics and accounting major John Duston said this year’s LARP would not be donating.

According to Duston, the group would like to add donations back into the event next year.   

“Next year, we hope to bring back the charitable donations, because that was something that Nik was really into, so we wanted to continue this legacy with that,” he said.

The rules of the game are simple: Any hits above the knee counted as a death while any hits below the elbow or knee meant a lost arm or leg. Headshots were discouraged, but not prohibited.

The simplicity allowed several bystanders to immediately join in and participate in the game.

“It’s just fun. If anyone else could come out here, be silly, hit each other with foam swords and get a pretty good workout … it’s pretty good,” Fraczek said.

Spanning over two hours, the warriors alternated among games of shirts versus skins, king of the hill, capture the flag and one-versus-one. Several warriors flung their arms around and slowly fell after being hit by a finishing blow, emphasizing the worthiness of their defeat.

Hunter McCoole, a communication major currently taking a hiatus from school, was walking her dog when she saw the warriors fighting outside her house.

“It looks like it was played safe. Everyone looked super stoked, and I think it’s great that everyone came outdoors and just had fun instead of being inside and studying,” McCoole said.

After 30 minutes of the LARP, Police Officer Andy Radujko stopped by on his motorcycle and took out his baton, jokingly ready to battle with the rest of the warriors.  

Radujko used to engage in a similar activity during high school and said it was great that Excursion Club was hosting the event.

Print

related.title: Vista Point: The Weekly Goings-On in Isla Vista
related.description: Valentines, anti-Valentines, free food, a capella for a good cause and more this week in I.V.
related.content:
SUCCULENTS
Santa Barbara Hillel will be hosting a Paint N’ Plant event to celebrate the Tu B’Shevat holiday. Attendees may paint pots and sow seeds this Thursday from 6:30 to 8 p.m. at 781 Embarcadero Del Mar.

ANTI-VALENTINE
Improvability will be hosting a double late-night improv comedy show on Friday. The first show is at 8 p.m. and doors open at 7:45 p.m. The second show is at 10 p.m. Tickets are $3 for the 8 p.m. show and $2 for the 10 p.m. show. The 10 p.m. performance is free to those who attend the 8 p.m. show.

TO SPEAK FOR THE TREES
Your Children’s Trees will be maintaining a coastal oak forest at Coal Oil Point Reserve from 9 a.m. to noon on Saturday. Organizers advise that interested volunteers bring water and wear closed-toe shoes and long pants. Biking to the reserve is also recommended.

BFOM
Brothas From Otha Mothas, UCSB’s all-male a cappella group, has a concert on Saturday at I.V. Theater from 8 to 10 p.m. Tickets are $5 at the door, and a portion of the proceeds will be going toward Camp Kesem, an organization that provides free summer camp programs to children whose parents have been affected by cancer.

LARPING FOR A CURE
Students can gather this weekend at Dog Shit Park to participate in live action role-playing (LARP), in which attendees beat each other up with foam-covered PVC pipes to raise money for Lymphoma research. The event will take place this Sunday at Dog Shit Park from 12 to 4 p.m. Organizers suggest bringing a $3 donation and a padded weapon.

DIY Valentine
The Isla Vista Food Co-op will be making Valentine’s gifts by hand. Join the Co-op as they hand-press flowers. Food will be provided for craft makers. The Co-op suggests donating $5 to participate, which will be donated to Supply & Create, a group that donates new and used art supplies to programs that need them, including the Boys & Girls Club. The event will be hosted at I.V. Food Co-op on Sunday from 12 to 2 p.m.

TALK OF THE TOWN
The UCSB Environmental Affairs Board (EAB) will host a “Talk, Tour, Taste” at the I.V. Food Co-op from 4 to 5 p.m. on Sunday. Attendees will join EAB members as they walk through the grocery store and sample various food merchandise.

VEGAN
A local nonprofit called Food Not Bombs will serve free vegan food at 5 p.m. this Sunday in Little Acorn Park (next to Bagel Café). Those interested in cooking can email organizers at foodnotbombsislavista@gmail.com. The dinner is regularly held every Sunday.

ALONE ON VALENTINE’S DAY?
Associated Students (A.S.) Program Board will be screening “The Edge of Seventeen” at I.V. Theater on Tuesday, Valentine’s Day, from 7 to 10 p.m. Admission to this coming-of-age film is free with an access card.

FREE FOOD
As part of its Gaucho Food Program, the Isla Vista Tenants Union and the I.V. Food Co-op will be tabling outside the Pardall Center on Wednesday from 10 a.m. to 2 p.m. to give away free food to UCSB students. This food giveaway is held every Wednesday.

A version of this story appeared on p.3 of the Thursday, Feb. 9, edition of the Daily Nexus.

related.title: Pardall, Del Norte To Get Traffic Lights
related.description: Santa Barbara County will install traffic signals this summer at the busy intersection between Pardall Road and Embarcadero Del Norte in Isla Vista’s business district.
related.content:
Santa Barbara County will install traffic signals this summer at the busy intersection between Pardall Road and Embarcadero Del Norte in Isla Vista’s business district.

Jenny Luo / Daily Nexus

According to the County Public Works Department, the project will cost approximately $300,000. Half of the funding will come from the public works department and the other half from UC Santa Barbara.

The project will begin in late summer, and the department estimates the project will take four to six weeks. The county will determine a specific start date after removing pre-existing streetlight infrastructure at the intersection.

Given the high traffic at the intersection, the construction will occur almost entirely on the sidewalk area. Some street shoulders are expected to be closed.

The intersection has two stop signs for northbound and southbound traffic, giving eastbound and westbound traffic the right of way at all times.

An increase in bike and car traffic over the years contributed to the change. Scott McGolpin, the county public works director, presented the project at an I.V. Community Network Meeting in January.

“This project should provide a much more orderly and functional intersection, safely integrating bicycle, pedestrian and auto traffic,” George Thurlow, the university’s liaison for I.V. affairs, said.

The original plan involved the installation of two traffic signals, one at the intersection of Pardall Road and Embarcadero Del Norte and the other at the intersection of Pardall Road and Embarcadero Del Mar.

The county determined that only one signal was necessary with the hope that the signal on Embarcadero Del Norte will cause sufficient breaks in the flow of traffic at the Embarcadero Del Mar intersection.

The county also proposed a four-way stop and a roundabout for this intersection, but officials concluded that neither would be able to safely sustain the amount of people on bikes coming through the intersection.

“It really came down to a traffic signal,” McGolpin said. “It will allow the bikes that are coming out of the campus to see the red bulb and slow down a little bit and allow the signal to go through a 15–20-second cycle. It’s definitely going to be new for I.V.”

Pegeen Soutar, the I.V. Recreation & Park District board chair and a 35-year I.V. resident, said she has noticed cars and delivery trucks having difficulty crossing while students ride their bicycles during the busiest times of the day.

“Safety is the biggest concern,” she said. “Whatever is put there, I hope people are paying attention and being careful.”

Correction: This story previously said the stoplight was funded by a grant. The Santa Barbara County Public Works Department and UCSB provided funding. 

A version of this story appeared on p.1 of the Thursday, Feb. 9, edition of the Daily Nexus.

related.title: Surf Report: Feb. 10 to 12
related.description: When are the swells swell? We'll let ya know.
related.content:
What up, brahs? Knew you’d be back again for the inside on catching the insides this weekend. Now, because of the overwhelming demand on my surf expertise, I have decided to bless ya with yet another completely accurate compilation of my surf report. If y’all didn’t catch that last bit of sarcasm, I wish you the best with reading the rest of this and hope you know these are surf predictions, not something to bet your life on.

In any case, let’s move on to the nitty gritty. Now, the west-northwest swell (WNW) is making an appearance this weekend, meaning those ocean storms are still blowing over here. It’s not the strongest surge, but it’s definitely causing some waves for us.

So let’s take a look at the three amigos, shall we?

Friday: best swells, worst weather; 4-6 feet, largest waves in the p.m.

Saturday: average swells, average weather; 3-5 feet, better surf in the a.m.

Sunday: eh swells, but great weather; 1-3 feet all day

Now, before you go running off asking the paddle boarders for some wax (please don’t), let me warn you about the rain coming on Friday. Oftentimes, rain means bacterial runoff being really present in the water during and after first day of rain. I know your surfing urges plunge you into the water despite possible sickness, but please be careful. Take care of yourself for finals, okay? Don’t say I never warned the freshies. Have a swell weekend!

Print
